description.plain:
Kris Kross was a 1990s chart-topping platinum-certified American rap duo comprised of Chris “Mac Daddy” Kelly and Chris “Daddy Mac” Smith.

One day in 1990, pre-teens Smith & Kelly were at an Atlanta mall trying to get an autograph from the short-lived trio Silk Tymes Leather when producer Jermaine Dupri was impressed with the boys' look, so he exchanged phone numbers with them. Dupri then spent two years writing music for the group, teaching them to rap, and trying to land them a record deal.

After being turned down several times, eventually Ruffhouse Records signed the duo after hearing “Lil Boys In Da Hood” because they liked the unique perspective of young rappers talking about the ghetto and gang violence.

In early 1992, Ruffhouse released Kris Kross' first single “Jump” to immediate global success. The track leapt to #1 on the Hot 100 and stayed there for eight weeks. It also hit #1 in four more countries and reached the top 10 in four others. Their debut album Totally Krossed Out also hit #1 in the US and would go 4x platinum.

The group’s second single “Warm It Up” reached the top 40 in eight countries. Two more singles from their debut album would find scattered chart success.

Kris Kross released two more albums over the next few years with moderate success. Both reached the top 20 in the US, and each spawned another top 20 hit on the Hot 100. Songs were written for a fourth album but it was never released. Instead the group split up with Kelly pursuing a career in music production and Smith studying business, later forming the companies Urbane Muse and One Life Entertainment.

In January 2013, the boys reunited to perform at a celebration marking 20 years in the business for Dupri’s record label So So Def. Sadly, four months later on Wednesday, May 1, 2013, Chris Kelly was found unresponsive in his Atlanta home and pronounced dead around 5 pm on the south campus of the Atlanta Medical Center; he was 34 years old.

songs.full_title: Jump by Kris Kross
songs.title: Jump

description.plain:
“Jump” is the hit debut single by the American Hip hop duo Kris Kross, released on February 6, 1992 – several weeks in advance of their debut studio album Totally Krossed Out. Producer Jermaine Dupri wrote the song after seeing people jumping at a concert he attended:

I watched the crowd. I watched how people were just into jumping … I went home and wrote the song in an hour.

The song had immediate success, with KKBT-FM program director and disc jockey ‘Big John’ Monds telling the LA Times, “‘Jump’ is one of those songs that when people hear it, they instantly love it.” The single quickly achieved international success, topping charts in Switzerland, Australia, and the United States – where it reached #1 faster than any debut single had in over 20 years. In 1992 alone, the song sold over 2 million physical copies.

Renowned music critic Robert Christgau praised the song, calling it, “one of those works of art that makes rock and roll worth living for.” An annual poll of music critics done by the Village Voice ranked the track as the #3 single of the year behind Arrested Development’s “Tennessee” and House Of Pain’s “Jump Around”.

Billboard reported “Jump” was the #3 song of 1992, and the #23 song of the decade.

songs.title: Warm It Up

description.plain:
“Warm It Up” was Kris Kross' second single behind their chart-topping debut “Jump”. Released June 4, 1992, it reached #13 on the Billboard Hot 100 that August, and topped the Rap chart.

It also peaked at #4 in Canada, #14 in Ireland, #16 in the UK, and reached the top 40 in seven other countries.

It’s title may be an homage (or copy) of Big Daddy Kane’s 1989 song “Warm It Up, Kane”, which was the flipside of his #1 rap song “Smooth Operator”.

description.plain: 2nd song from Kris Kross' 3rd LP Young Rich and Dangerous, “Live and Die for Hip Hop” was a song featuring Da Brat, Mr Black, Aaliyah and Jermaine Dupri. It was the first appearance of Mr Black and one of the few appearances. It was the 2nd single from the album. The song was performed at Kris Kross' reunion in 2013 at the SoSoDef 20th Anniversary Concert but only featured Mac Daddy and Daddy Mac’s verse. Of course, months later, Chris “Mac Daddy” Kelly Passed. The song was remixed by DJ Clarke Kent and put in EP Best of Kris Kross Remixed ‘92 '94 '96.

songs.full_title: Alright by Kris Kross (Ft. Super Cat)
songs.title: Alright

description.plain:
6th song from Da Bomb, Kris Kross' second album, “Alright” was a song with a positive message. The song featured famous R&B singer Super Cat and attempted to diss kid rap group “Da Youngsta’s.” They somewhat misfired but the song was received well by fans. The first single from the album, Alright was remixed for EP, Best of Kris Kross Remixed ‘92 '94 '96 and even had its own EP.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M9kr_K5rH5M

songs.full_title: Tonite's Tha Night by Kris Kross (Ft. Trey Lorenz)
songs.title: Tonite’s Tha Night

description.plain: Tonite’s tha Night is the first single from rap duo Kris Kross' third and final album, Young, Rich & Dangerous. It featured background vocals from Trey Lorenz and had a remix that featured Redman. The single was certified gold on January 17, 1996. This song was so smooth and laidback, definitely one of the duo’s best songs.

songs.full_title: Da Bomb by Kris Kross (Ft. Da Brat)
songs.title: Da Bomb

description.plain: The 2nd song of the 2nd album of Kris Kross' album Da Bomb, “Da Bomb” was a song featuring the debut of artist from SoSoDef, Da Brat. The song was released in 1994 as a single opposed to the album and the other singles from the album released in 1993. The song was also remixed for EP Best of Kris Kross Remixed ‘92 '94 '96. People critiqued the song highly for its use of lyrics 'I drop bombs like Hiroshima’ despite that this was a sample from RBX in “High Powered” from Dr Dre’s The Chronic

songs.full_title: I Missed the Bus by Kris Kross
songs.title: I Missed the Bus

description.plain: “I Missed the Bus” was the third single from Totally Krossed Out and the group’s first to not reach #1 on Billboard’s Rap chart, peaking at #14. It also reached #63 on the Pop chart. The track samples “Baretta’s Theme (Keep Your Eye on the Sparrow)” by Sammy Davis, Jr.

songs.full_title: The Way of Rhyme by Kris Kross
songs.title: The Way of Rhyme

description.plain:
Though not released as a commercially-available single, “The Way Of The Rhyme” was sent to radio stations and a promotional music video was made for it.

The track begins with a sample of the theme song of the television show Barney Miller and ends with a sample of the bass line from the end of “More Peas” by Fred Wesley and The J.B.’s.

The live version of the song featured in the music video was released on the promotional version of the CD single for “I Missed The Bus”.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iuepTrSJSRQ

annotatable.link_title: The Way of Rhyme by Kris Kross
annotatable.title: The Way of Rhyme

body.plain:
Though not released as a commercially-available single, “The Way Of The Rhyme” was sent to radio stations and a promotional music video was made for it.

The track begins with a sample of the theme song of the television show Barney Miller and ends with a sample of the bass line from the end of “More Peas” by Fred Wesley and The J.B.’s.

The live version of the song featured in the music video was released on the promotional version of the CD single for “I Missed The Bus”.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iuepTrSJSRQ

songs.full_title: It's A Shame by Kris Kross
songs.title: It’s A Shame

description.plain: “It’s a Shame” was the fourth and final commercially-released single from Totally Krossed Out and the group’s first to not chart on the Hot 100, peaking at #11 on the Rap chart. It was more successful overseas, reaching the top 40 in Ireland, Belgium, New Zealand and the UK.

songs.full_title: I'm Real by Kris Kross
songs.title: I’m Real

description.plain:
7th track on Kris Kross' 2nd album Da Bomb, “I’m Real” was the first single from the album. The song references other songs in past albums and the album the song is in, such as “It Don’t Stop (Hip-Hop Classic)” and songs like, Jump. The song was even performed on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno in April 1993, before Da Bomb was released.

description.plain:
“Lil' Boys in da Hood” is the song that got producer Jermaine Dupri and his young rap outfit Kris Kross a record deal with Ruffhouse Records in the spring of 1991.

It was also the b-side to their international smash hit “Jump”.
